page.title: 02The Ashby Canal.
page.content: The Ashby canal,originally,some 30 miles in length,was constructed to carry coal from the South Derbyshire coal field.It now survives in a shortened form as a recreational amenity. The canal was established as a result of the initiative of the second Earl of Moira who stood to gain from the cheaper carriage of coal from his Moira collieries. The Canal was started at Moira,some 8 miles south of Burton_on_Trent in 1794 and reached the Coventry canal in 1804.It followed the natural contours of the land but encountered difficulties such as the dispute with the right honourable Penn Asherton Curzon of Gopsall who insisted that the line of the canal be re_routed so as not to interfere with plans for extending his hunting pack.
